Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor surprised me in the best possible way.
I expected a simple auto shooter, but the game turned out to be one of the most satisfying, content-packed and addictive experiences in the genre. If you enjoy build crafting, steady progression and constant action, this one hits all the right notes.

What the game does incredibly well

A visual style that fits perfectly

The graphics are not aiming for realism. Instead, you get a bold and charming art style that makes every run easy to read and fun to look at. The chunky designs and cave atmosphere match the chaotic gameplay beautifully.

Gameplay that never feels the same

Every run feels like a fresh challenge. You level up, pick from three upgrades, discover crazy build synergies and collect resources while dealing with endless swarms. Random loot drops give your character permanent bonuses and the meta progression between missions keeps you improving even when you fail.

The loop is simple to understand but hard to put down. You are always making meaningful decisions about farming, fighting or upgrading, and the game constantly rewards experimentation.

Weapons with real personality

Each weapon feels distinct and becomes even more fun as you unlock new tiers. Many upgrades change how the weapon behaves, not just its numbers. This leads to wild combinations and playstyles you would not expect at first glance.

Classes that actually matter

There are four classes with three variations each. Every variant pushes you toward a specific approach, whether you prefer aggressive play, tanking or resource gathering. None of the options feel useless or broken. They all bring something unique to the table.

Tons of content and replay value

There are multiple biomes, challenges, masteries, escort missions and a huge number of builds to try. The game keeps giving you new goals and new ideas to test. It is easy to get lost in all the possibilities.

Very satisfying sound work

The music is fine, but the sound effects are excellent. Drilling, blasting and crushing enemies always feels punchy and clean. The feedback is great and makes every moment more enjoyable.

â¸»

Small things that could be improved

The escape timer after the boss

I understand the purpose of the timer. It prevents endless farming and adds tension. Still, it can feel a bit stressful at times. A slightly longer window would make the ending feel more rewarding.

RNG heavy missions

Some missions, especially mastery and challenge ones, can feel too dependent on early luck. A bad start can snowball quickly. It does not ruin the game, but you will notice it from time to time.

â¸»

Final thoughts

Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor is easily one of the best auto shooters available today.
It is fast, clever, full of character and bursting with progression. The game encourages you to try new builds, explore new ideas and dive into chaotic fights that never feel boring.

If you like games with loot, upgrades and endless replayability, this is a must play.

Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor is not DRG2 - nor does it try to be. Instead, it adapts the authentic DRG experience into an all-new Survivors-like, complete with mining, objectives, dwarves (well, one dwarf), and lots of bugs (the squishy kind, not the ones that ruin your experience).

Like many Survivors-likes, DRG:Survivor is easily accessible to new players while offering a surprising depth and a plethora of viable end-game builds as well as great replayability (as evidenced by my total play time).

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
DRG:Survivor's gameplay is pretty much peak DRG. Unlike many traditional Survivors-likes, each run is divided into multiple stages, each with their own finale and an additional objective. The gameplay loop is surprisingly similar to the original's Deep Dives - mine minerals, complete your objective, get to the drop pod, rinse and repeat.

The EXP system, on the other hand, is similar enough to other Survivors-likes that players familiar with those will feel right at home. Collect EXP orbs, pick one of three upgrades, get stronger.

[h2]Weapons & Upgrades[/h2]
If you played DRG, you will instantly recognise many weapons in DRG:Survivor. While not a straight port (obviously), even the roles and purposes of individual weapons translate well into the Survivors-like genre. During a normal run, you will unlock up to four weapons at level 5, 15 and 25 respectively which can be upgraded with stat upgrades and overclocks during a run.

Also like the original, DRG:Survivor's weapons and upgrades are somewhat imbalanced. While the auto-cannon, for instance, is extremely powerful with the right builld, many other weapons will feel inadequate on Hazard 5.

[h2]Achievements[/h2]
Although DRG:Survivor sports many of the usual achievements you can get just by playing, some of the rarer ones pose an actual challenge. This adds immensely to the replayability but can get frustrating for certain completionists.

[h2]Conclusion (AKA the "But how does it hold up against <insert Survivors-like of your choice>?" section)[/h2]
DRG:Survivor is definitely in the top percentile of Survivors-likes. While the game is ultimately a nod to the DRG community, even players without any experience in Deep Rock Galactic can jump right in.

Although some of the mechanics such as mining, additional objectives and the relatively new gear system can feel unfamiliar or even daunting, this game is not easier or more difficult to pick up than any other Survivors-like. Unlike some of the more niche titles, DRG:Survivor also offers an active and (mostly) helpful community and wiki, making it a good starting point into the Survivors-like genre as well.

I've played this game a lot since it first released in early access and continued to iterate on the game.  The end result, at least of their 1.0, is that they just never addressed so many of the myriad problems with the game.

Weapon balance is terrible.  It has always been terrible since the early days and has barely been addressed.  A large percentage of the weapons are so bad they actively make you weaker by having them, since you get offered upgrades for your other weapons less often.  Some weapons are so strong that they will carry an entire run by themselves.

Visibility is terrible.  There is no mechanism to see aliens which are visually behind something.  The game has an isometric style, where the camera is top down but slanted in a way that you see the bottom side of things, but not the top.  Any aliens "north" of terrain are completely invisible.  This extends to being behind the escort vehicle, mineable resources, trees, crystals, etc.  Weapon effects also render over top of enemies.  You will routinely take damage from running into enemies that have never been visible on your screen.

Information availability is terrible.  Do you know want to know which weapons are available to the scout?  Too bad.  Do you want to know the stats of a weapon you're about to select from a level-up?  Too bad.  Do you want to know how much damage your existing weapon does?  First, you have to ESC, then click into each individual weapon.  Next, damage over time is not credited to the source weapon whatsoever.  If you're any kind of status effect build, all of the damage pools into one giant damage type that you can't even view until the postgame screen.  There is no way to know how much damage each of your fire weapons is contributing.

Meta progression is ridiculous.  I have millions of credits and thousands of each meta resource from playing so much in early access.  You now not only have meta upgrades, but also gear that randomly drops during the game.  These items have *enormous* pools of stats and can cost a few hundred thousand credits to fully upgrade.  One of the item types is the only way for a class to have access to more weapon types, so you're unable to even go down that route until you RNG them.

A piece of gear can have 60 armor or >100 hp in addition to multiple other stats.  A legendary armor upgrade in game is 15 armor.  Armor has a dramatic dropoff in effectiveness, so not only does armor become a completely wasted upgrade in game, but if you don't have these big pieces you're going to be taking 4x the incoming damage.  Keep in mind that even with this much armor you can still take half or more of your hp in a single hit from big enemies on danger 5.

The amount of weapons / tag spread is too small.  You naturally want your weapons to overlap in as many ways as possible so that you can maximally share the category upgrades.  For example, 20% projectile damage gives more benefit if all 4 weapons use projectiles than with just 2.  However, there aren't actually that many weapons with good overlap.  Outside of kinetic and projectile, there are pitifully few for many of the other types.  Some weapons have upgrades that change their damage type, but you can't plan around that since there's a high chance it doesn't appear and many of those that change type are in the "these weapons suck" category.  Between the general power (or lack thereof) for some weapons, and the availability of synergistic options, you end up building toward the same options far too often.

The game is cheap.  It's an OK game to play here and there, but it quickly becomes an exercise in frustration due to all the never addressed issues.

'Challenging' and 'Unreasonable' are entirely different concepts. 
Make the developers play missions on Hazard 5 every month.
And if they fail to clear it, their pay should be docked and given in Red Sugar and Nitra.

 [b] **I really don't like that upgrades, and content are locked behind higher hazards/difficulties [/b] Sure I might've not played the game enough to really see every overclock or every build but I just can't go farther. Don't get me wrong, if you do like that then thats a plus, but for me, and other people, that is a major reason to not play the game any more. It's frustrating when you're forced to play hazard 2, 3, even 4 for some perma weapon upgrades. It's even more frustrating considering that this type of game is increasingly more dependent on luck the higher hazard you go on. 

[b] I was also expecting more from the weapon overclocks.[/b] As someone who really enjoys overclocks from deep rock galactic itself, I was expecting more play styles for each weapon. Instead, for most of the weapons theres just a generic + reload speed and + fire rate, or +magazine size or -reload speed. Theres also a lack of clean overclocks, which might be a design thing but i feel left out. Then the big unstable overclocks, you'd expect some gigantic change of weapon play style, but for some of the weapons it's just more generic nonsense. A few of the weapons have really interesting upgrades, like sentries can follow you around, or destroy terrain, A good few of the weapons can switch what type of damage they deal out, but most of em? [h1] Theres some good here though [/h1]

Supply pods are really nice, being able to give you much needed space, and the artifacts seem to have a great amount of variety. The classes also seem to have variety and unique play styles which i really enjoyed before i reached my limit. The upgrades you get with minerals are nice too, though [b] I wish i felt.. more.. from them. 1% move speed or 1% mining speed, or even +1 to starting nitra.... it doesn't feel like it changes anything. [/b]

For what it's worth, this game has a lot right, and theres many things i didn't mention such as price, longevity, or the cave generation; thats because i didn't have a major opinion on em, so to me they're good. However, I ended up just being disappointed, I wanted more. I expected more considering the branding. Maybe thats my fault? To be fair, it's only been a month and a bit since it got fully released, so maybe as the game updates and changes, so will my opinion. 

[b] This game is 100% for a certain audience, but I'm not that audience. The biggest gripe i have is the upgrades and content being locked behind higher difficulties. I just can't recommend it, I gave it as much a chance as i was willing, but at this current moment it's not a game i wanna come back to. Good luck to the devs, and I really hope this game turns into a delicious pizza with more time for it to cook. [/b]

There's the bones of a great game in there, but in its current state it feels like the devs ran out of ideas halfway through. I got to Hazard 3 which is meant to be the midpoint but I simply lost all interest because the only realistic way to progress further is a brutal and quite frankly really boring grind (actually, it's more like four separate grinds due to the amount of systems they put in) to increase power through extremely bland meta progression.

Hurray, one run gives me enough currency to increase my critical hit damage by 2% and two pieces of gear that are 0.206% better than what I'm currently wearing in those slots. Zzzzz.

The way the game presents numbers like upgrade percentages and damage is also incredibly poor, making trying to evaluate upgrades a complete crapshoot for most stats. Like yeah, sure, I can see the stat equation is "((Base * skill) + flat) * meta * overclock * artifact * mutator)" (I'm not joking, that's literally what the ingame tooltip says) but that doesn't actually *mean* anything to anyone who isn't some old EVE theorycrafter who can't enjoy a game unless it requires 6 separate spreadsheets.

Past a fairly early point, every run feels the same apart from there being two different game modes (and Escort, while decent in itself, is badly overtuned). Almost every weapon feels the same. The only meaningful build choice you have most runs is whether to go for direct damage or DoT build, and even that has minimal impact on how you actually play.

Upgrades don't feel meaningful; at best a "legendary" upgrade compensates for some inherent weakness a particular weapon has (like adding more beams to a flamethrower to make it more consistent), but there's basically no power fantasy of getting lucky and piecing together a really strong build. I played about 30 runs to get to Hazard 3 and honestly, I can't think of any that felt memorable in any way.

If a weapon feels different or unique, it's generally a bad thing because it has some major downside that makes it a pain to play with, like the minigun only firing forwards in your movement direction which requires constant micromanagement. Or you could just, you know, pick a different weapon that *doesn't* have a major downside, while feeling similarly strong (not that any weapon really feels strong, at best they feel adequate for keeping up with enemy spawn rate unless you massively overgear the difficulty).

Same goes for the mastery objectives that I assume are meant to shake up how you play, but most of the time it feels like you're either forced to play with a bad / boring weapon or do other really arbitrary things ("stand still for 60 seconds") in order to, you guessed it, advance the meta progression that you need to get stronger.

In that regard the game feels like it has actually regressed since earlier EA builds, by simply nerfing anything that could be strong/fun and adding several more layers of meta progression grind, plus the addition of forced timers that make you play the game only at the pace imagined by the developers, with barely any space left for being creative with how you play a map/run.

The core of the game (a slower paced take on survivor genre leveraging terrain manipulation and DRG assets) is fundamentally solid, so I'm happy to believe it'll get better with time. But right now it's just too grindy, too samey run to run and not enough fun (strong builds) to be had to keep my interest.

I've played this game a lot since it first released in early access and continued to iterate on the game.  The end result, at least of their 1.0, is that they just never addressed so many of the myriad problems with the game.

Weapon balance is terrible.  It has always been terrible since the early days and has barely been addressed.  A large percentage of the weapons are so bad they actively make you weaker by having them, since you get offered upgrades for your other weapons less often.  Some weapons are so strong that they will carry an entire run by themselves.

Visibility is terrible.  There is no mechanism to see aliens which are visually behind something.  The game has an isometric style, where the camera is top down but slanted in a way that you see the bottom side of things, but not the top.  Any aliens "north" of terrain are completely invisible.  This extends to being behind the escort vehicle, mineable resources, trees, crystals, etc.  Weapon effects also render over top of enemies.  You will routinely take damage from running into enemies that have never been visible on your screen.

Information availability is terrible.  Do you know want to know which weapons are available to the scout?  Too bad.  Do you want to know the stats of a weapon you're about to select from a level-up?  Too bad.  Do you want to know how much damage your existing weapon does?  First, you have to ESC, then click into each individual weapon.  Next, damage over time is not credited to the source weapon whatsoever.  If you're any kind of status effect build, all of the damage pools into one giant damage type that you can't even view until the postgame screen.  There is no way to know how much damage each of your fire weapons is contributing.

Meta progression is ridiculous.  I have millions of credits and thousands of each meta resource from playing so much in early access.  You now not only have meta upgrades, but also gear that randomly drops during the game.  These items have *enormous* pools of stats and can cost a few hundred thousand credits to fully upgrade.  One of the item types is the only way for a class to have access to more weapon types, so you're unable to even go down that route until you RNG them.

A piece of gear can have 60 armor or >100 hp in addition to multiple other stats.  A legendary armor upgrade in game is 15 armor.  Armor has a dramatic dropoff in effectiveness, so not only does armor become a completely wasted upgrade in game, but if you don't have these big pieces you're going to be taking 4x the incoming damage.  Keep in mind that even with this much armor you can still take half or more of your hp in a single hit from big enemies on danger 5.

The amount of weapons / tag spread is too small.  You naturally want your weapons to overlap in as many ways as possible so that you can maximally share the category upgrades.  For example, 20% projectile damage gives more benefit if all 4 weapons use projectiles than with just 2.  However, there aren't actually that many weapons with good overlap.  Outside of kinetic and projectile, there are pitifully few for many of the other types.  Some weapons have upgrades that change their damage type, but you can't plan around that since there's a high chance it doesn't appear and many of those that change type are in the "these weapons suck" category.  Between the general power (or lack thereof) for some weapons, and the availability of synergistic options, you end up building toward the same options far too often.

The game is cheap.  It's an OK game to play here and there, but it quickly becomes an exercise in frustration due to all the never addressed issues.

My take isn't going to be popular, because everyone likes to think of themselves as an elite gamer....
But this game is too hard...
This would be a GREAT multiplayer game... But for some reason whenever anyone makes something in the vampire survivors style, they don't do that. But single player? This is just running around in circles, maybe getting a few enemies down as more of them swarm in and barely managing to mine the materials you need.

There's an escort mission, this absolutely sucks. They are brutally difficult. Even on lower difficulties...
I want to like this game, but it needs an easier difficulty.

You do get stronger with gear, as it slowly drip feeds you some, I've been playing for 8 hours and have barely found any pieces of gear. It filled all the slots and then just kinda stopped bothering to give me any gear. You find the gear in level in the forms of briefcases, but they drop extremely rarely. The most I've found on one level is 3 bad pieces of gear. But usually I find at most, 1.

Whenever you get a boss down, you have 30 seconds to get out of the level, or it's game over.... Why the hurry? Let me pick up my goddamned loot! Oh, I missed a single flower for a quest, but despite needing only 6 of the stupid things, they're often extremely sparse. Or I need to mine 10 more of the blue ore... but I just can't find any. Sometimes, I swear, there just isn't enough on the level to do the quest. Randomly generated areas for you...
Personally, I'd prefer the level didn't end, until you finished off the rest of the enemies, and they stopped spawning. That would be way more fun... But no, it's get in or lose.

The dwarves cannot be customised at all. There's additional skins that cost money... There's no female dwarf (Another hot topic among gamers.) You can't even recolour the dwarves... Or unlock fun hats.

The weapons are a mix between awful, and slightly less awful. There's none that you can aim with your mouse. This is a huge problem for me... Different weapons aim slightly different. Some rotate around you, some shoot behind you, some shoot in front of you... Some just shoot the nearest enemy, or the strongest enemy.... But unlike Soulstone Survivors, where you can choose to have aiming be automatic, or actually aimed by yourself, quickly on the fly... There's no weapon that you aim... So your mouse isn't needed on this game... You only need WASD. Which gets really old, really fast. 
You can use your mouse to select upgrades between level ups... Annoyingly, right click pauses the game. There's no way to rebind this. So if like me, you have fat heavy hands, expect to randomly pause occasionally, it's very annoying.


Levels take a long time, and when you die, there's no recovery or 3 continues or the robot to bring you back up... You're just dead, it's just over... You do get XP and stuff, which is nice... But it takes a very long time to progress this way...
The game feels extremely slow, because for the first few runs, you're very likely to die... And that's boring.
Who likes dying in games? (Okay, there's bound to be someone out there who does, but it ain't me!)

I hate to give this game a not recommended, because I know I'll probably enjoy it once I've slotted in enough work hours to unlock the fun part... But when you have to invest a ton of time to get to the fun part of a game.... a goddamned video game, not a job... Then it's just not something I can recommend.

For instance, I play WoW... It's an MMO, you have to invest a lot of time to get to the fun parts... Consequently, I do not recommend it to anyone... But I still play it.
I'll continue playing this game.. I might even add an update to this review to let you all know if it gets better eventually... But I will still recommend against it. Because quite frankly, if it's not fun within the first two hours (Refund hours) then it's not something I can recommend. 

Quite frankly, the grind should be fun. You should enjoy grinding because that's part of the game as well.
If you're not having fun grinding, and getting your levels up, and getting gear... then why are you playing? Go play a game that's fun from the get go instead.

So no, I cannot recommend this game.
Sorry devs... maybe make the game more fun and I might change my mind...
And add customisation....
And a female dwarf. Like c'mon, why's it men only? There are tonnes of badass dwarven women in media. But no, the incels in your community will throw a hissyfit if you do.

If you play this game anyway, I hope you have fun...
If you don't, can't blame you.
Regardless, whether you liked my review, hated it, think I'm a moron... or didn't even read the review and just skipped to the end, I hope you have a wonderful day. <3

it's not bad, but i don't think i would be playing DRG: survivor if i wasn't already a fan of DRG. mining, and how you have to plan efficiently around gathering minerals while also fighting is very cool, but it's the one purely good nugget buried in this game.

the approach to difficulty is just disappointing. it's one of those games where the main way of making it "harder" is by increasing enemy stats (hp, speed, damage) in lock-step with one's own character progression, meaning that, while there will be bigger numbers on the screen, there's not really any sensation of getting any stronger, because everything is taking about the same amount of time to deal with. this couples poorly with the meta upgrade system, which ultimately adds nothing other than a way for the developer to keep the player from progressing "too quickly" through the otherwise relatively simple gameplay.

DRG: survivor was definitely missing something in it's early access form, but i do not think the gear system added in 1.0 fills that space. there's nothing unique about how it works, no interesting decisions to be made, and it just feels like an afterthought. 

I don't hate it, but this game will not respect your time, and i sort of wish i had been playing almost any other brainless fidget game instead.
